docs.lead_paragraph: Macie Mull was 82 and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for more than a decade when she developed pneumonia. Her nursing home rushed her to the hospital where she spent the night, receiving intravenous antibiotics. The next day she was back at the nursing home, more confused than ever. Now she was choking on her puréed food; eating was becoming impossible. And so, one Sunday afternoon, the administrators of her nursing home in Hickory, N.C., asked Mrs. Mull's daughter what to do: Did she want a feeding tube inserted? At that point, Mrs. Mull muttered only a few random words and could no longer recognize her daughter. The feeding tube would almost certainly prolong her life, but was it worth it?

headline.main: When Alzheimer's Steals the Mind, How Aggressively to Treat the Body?

docs.abstract: Experts and family members debate how agressively patients with late-stage Alzheimer's should be treated; Dr Susan Mitchell of Harvard University and Hebrew Rehabilitation Home for Aged studied nursing home patients and found late-stage Alzheimer's patients often receive more aggressive medical treatment than other terminal patients near death; cost of treatments, pain for patient and impact of prolonged procedures figure into decision whether to intervene with feeding tubes and intravenous fluids or allow patient to die; Dr Douglas Nelson, Hickory, North Carolina, geriatrician, wrote position paper, which was unanimously passed by state medical society and discourages use of feeding tube for late-stage Alzheimer's patients, but admits many families are unable to let aged relative die; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A health-conscious woman asked me the other day whether she should be taking magnesium with her calcium. I thought not, but that was before I had examined the many studies defining the role of this too-often-ignored mineral nutrient. Magnesium is important to nearly every function and tissue in the body, from the heart to the bones and nearly everything in between. It plays a critical role in a vast array of acute and chronic diseases. Some 350 enzyme functions depend on it, including the enzyme that generates energy for every cell in the body.

headline.main: A Dietary Mineral You Need (and Probably Didn't Know It)

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses often overlooked mineral nutrient magnesium; Dr Mildred S Seelig, retired University of North Carolina professor and author of The Magnesium Factor, explains disorders that can cause magnesium deficiency and role of magnesium in overall health; suggests two to one ratio of calcium to magnesium; dietary sources of magnesium discussed; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of badgering by AIDS activists and health officials, the Bush administration has finally come to its senses and found a way to provide cheap generic drugs and single-pill combinations of drugs to millions of people infected with the AIDS virus in Africa and the Caribbean. It is a welcome shift that could save vast numbers of lives. The administration won plaudits last year when it announced a $15 billion program to combat AIDS in poor nations. But that deserved applause turned into dismay when the administration balked at paying for the treatments the World Health Organization deemed the most effective. These medications, from foreign manufacturers, combine three patented AIDS drugs into a single pill that is cheaper and far easier to take than the individual drugs. The administration said it had doubts about the safety of the combined pills, but it might also have wanted to protect its patrons in the drug industry.

headline.main: The Global Battle Against AIDS; Progress on Pills

docs.abstract: Editorial says Bush administration has finally found way to provide cheap generic drugs and single-pill combinations of drugs to millions of people infected with AIDS virus in Africa and Caribbean, after months of badgering by AIDS activists and health officials; says Food and Drug Administration's expedited review process announced by Health and Human Services Sec Tommy Thompson could save vast numbers of lives

docs.lead_paragraph: Neither outlandish salaries nor labor strikes, not pine tar nor pharmaceuticals seem to be able to keep us baseball fans away from the game. But Fay Vincent, one of baseball's most diligent guardians, remembers how the cocaine scandal of the mid-1980's threatened the major leagues' immune system as steroids have yet to do. ''There was a point during the cocaine crisis where we were on the verge of seeing a real fan revolt,'' Vincent, commissioner of baseball from 1989 to 1992, said in an interview. ''I threw Steve Howe out of baseball for life after eight drug violations,'' and six previous suspensions. ''The union is ludicrous, it doesn't seem to care what a player does. But the players getting caught up in cocaine significantly jeopardized fans' trust.''

headline.main: BackTalk; Baseball Fans Have Become Enablers

docs.abstract: Gregory Jordan BackTalk column contends that seeming apathy of baseball fans to steroid use among players--and public appetite for record-breaking and dazzling displays of power--is going to make drug problem worse eventually; photo (M)
